As I see it, digital twins hold immense potential to revolutionize healthcare. These virtual models of organs, systems, or even entire bodies empower healthcare professionals to simulate treatments, predict outcomes, and proactively manage health conditions in real time. By allowing various treatment options to be tested before any physical intervention, digital twins offer a personalized approach that enhances diagnostics, surgery, and chronic disease management. This capability can indeed save lives by enabling more precise interventions with fewer errors, ensuring timely care.  
In my experience with Electronic Health Records (EHR) projects, I've seen how digital twins can integrate with EHR systems to provide seamless access to patient data. This integration is essential for ensuring information accuracy, facilitating quality monitoring in healthcare delivery, and improving overall patient outcomes.  
  
For instance, we tackled challenges such as converting brand-name drugs to generics in electronic prescriptions to prevent overdoses and identifying drug interactions to enhance patient safety. I would definitely say that digital twins are a game-changer in healthcare, empowering providers to deliver more effective, personalized care.

I think imagining a world without personal cars is pretty cool. I mean, societies have functioned without cars not that long ago, you know? It just takes some rethinking of how things are set up. Like, public transportation would have to be way more reliable and accessible. In cities, we're already seeing how bikes and scooters are a thing, right? And in small towns, you might have community shuttles or better train systems that are more frequent and connect rural and urban areas. 

In terms of daily life and commodities, I imagine local communities would play a bigger role. If goods were locally sourced, that would mean less need to transport stuff long distances. People might walk or bike for groceries or errands. Someone I know moved to a tiny town and told me, "I shop at a farmer's market. I know the people running it, and it makes a big difference in my day-to-day life." Stuff like deliveries would lean on drones or shared transportation. 

We’d also need better online systems for working and accessing services from home. Remote work, telemedicine… these are more common now, but we'd have to fully embrace that change. It's about reshaping how we think of distance and travel. Humans are super adaptable. Once you have a community structure that supports these changes, living without personal cars doesn't seem too wild. 

I've even started walking more to get around my neighborhood to get a feel for how those changes might look. Maybe there’s something we can learn from how things used to be, blend it with tech, and make it modern. I keep thinking there's something there, or maybe not... I'm just musing...

What a load of nonsense. People have been dreaming about immortality since forever, and it’s always just out of reach, like some kind of carrot on a stick. Let’s get real: the world’s already falling apart with overpopulation, climate change, and resource depletion. Now imagine we add thousands of immortal humans consuming resources forever. It sounds more like a nightmare than a dream.

Sure, medical advancements are awesome, but believing that they’ll make us live forever is just sci-fi fantasy. Most countries can't even provide basic healthcare right now; you really think medicine’s gonna suddenly solve aging like it’s some minor inconvenience? It’s like people want to ignore science when it says you can’t drink a miracle smoothie to live longer, but embrace it when it promises never-ending life.

Honestly, I’d rather focus on improving the years we have rather than chasing after the impossible. Immortality could mean endless work, never retiring, and the same political struggles repeating on loop. If that’s what you want, go ahead and keep dreaming. But personally, I'm ready to face the fact that life has a natural end, as it should. Living a full, meaningful life beats sticking around forever any day.

\> Renewables+storage are vastly cheaper & simpler.

That's a straight lie. Not only does the technology not even exist to do storage at scale the amount of storage we could achieve is unfathomably more expensive than nuclear.

Look at the latest Lazard's Levelized Cost of Energy+ study. Renewables are about half the cost of nuclear power. Renewables + 4 hours of storage is price competitive with nuclear. As it turns out, it can be cloudy and the air can be still at the same time. And it can do those 2 things for extended periods of time. To have a reliable renewable based grid, you need to be able to run exclusively off batteries FOR WEEKS.

\> Although reasonably high levels of reliability can be reached by solar-wind resources alone, the defining challenge of such systems are the longer-duration gaps, often associated with extreme weather episodes. For instance, historical solar and wind resources data in Germany reveal that there were nearly 2 weeks in which dispatchable generation had to cover practically all of the demand because of a period with very low solar and wind power availability (called “dark doldrums”)

\> \[...\]

\> For example, the energy storage capacities we consider are in some cases quite large: energy storage equal to 12 h of mean electricity demand in the contiguous U.S., Germany, and Japan represents 5.6, 0.7, and 1.4 TWh, respectively (Supplementary Data 5). These combined storage capacities represent \~35 times the capacity of Li-ion batteries produced globally to date, and more than 200 times the pumped hydro storage capacities that now exist in those countries.

[https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-26355-z](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-26355-z)

To reiterate: 12 hours of storage for 3 countries requires 35 times more storage than has been produced in history. And we need several weeks worth of storage for every country.

Storage isn't even a solved problem yet. We literally can't do it. To say that it is simpler and cheaper is insane.
